content:
One example of a story where the depiction of the landscape plays a significant role is "The Great Gatsby" by F. Scott Fitzgerald. In the novel, the landscape of the East Egg and West Egg neighborhoods, as well as the Valley of Ashes, represents the social and economic class differences that exist in the story's world.

The opulent and luxurious landscape of the wealthy East Egg neighborhood, where Gatsby and the Buchanans live, represents the upper class's excess and extravagance. On the other hand, the less refined and gritty landscape of the Valley of Ashes, where George and Myrtle Wilson live, symbolizes the social and economic struggle of the working-class.

Additionally, the setting of the novel, New York City, serves as an essential backdrop to the story's events, highlighting the contrast between the wealthy and glamorous side of the city and its darker, more sordid underbelly. The use of the landscape throughout the novel helps to reinforce the novel's themes of wealth, class, and social mobility, contributing to the story's overall impact.
